content: quote: The man spoke plainly as he explained the horrors he lived through in a Kosovo Liberation Army prison camp 10 years ago. He told me about how he watched people beaten with steel pipes, cut with knives, left for days without food, and shot and killed. "What can you feel when you see those things?" he said. "It's something that is stuck in my mind for the rest of my life. You cannot do those things to people, not even to animals." As the man talked, his mother paced nervously in the nearby kitchen. She was panicked and tears were streaming down her face. "They'll kill him, they'll kill him," she moaned, clutching one of her grandchildren. But her son persisted. We spent hours in the family's sitting room as our source detailed allegations of possible war crimes by KLA officers in a military camp in the Albanian border town of Kukes. It was a crucial interview for a delicate story I have been investigating for years. Mystery of the missing I had met sources who spoke vaguely about secret camps in Albania where Kosovo Serbs, Albanians and Roma were interrogated, tortured and in most cases killed. I met another source who agreed to share important details about KLA prison camps. This man cut a very different profile. He had returned from a successful career abroad to join the KLA in its fight for Kosovo's independence from Serbia. The man was still proud of the goals he fought for, but he had become haunted by the treatment of civilians he had seen at a KLA prison camp. More than that, he said he felt angry and betrayed by KLA commanders who tolerated and even ordered the abuses. "It didn't seem strange at the time," he told me as he described seeing desperate civilians locked in a filthy agricultural shed. He said the civilians were Serbs and Roma seized by KLA soldiers and were being hidden away from Nato troops. The source believes the captives were sent across the border to Albania and killed. "Now, looking back, I know that some of the things that were done to innocent civilians were wrong. But the people who did these things act as if nothing happened, and continue to hurt their own people, Albanians." This man was one of eight former KLA fighters who revealed some of their darkest secrets from the war. A soldier's story Yet another source spoke of driving trucks packed with shackled prisoners - mainly Serbian civilians from Kosovo - to secret locations in Albania where they were eventually killed. He recalled hearing two of the captives begging to be shot rather than tortured and "cut into pieces". "I was sick. I was just waiting for it to end," the source told me. "It was hard. I thought we were fighting a war [of liberation] but this was something completely different." (.....) These are the people Clinton helped in 1999, and Bush recognized their independence in 2008. At the time of their recognition, their “president” was a former KLA member and under suspicion (Wanted, if not a friend of ours) of committing war crimes! This goes along side what Carla Del Ponte wrote in her book last year about organ smuggling in northern Albania. +http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7990984.stm "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

She was panicked and tears were streaming down her face. "They'll kill him, they'll kill him," she moaned, clutching one of her grandchildren. But her son persisted. We spent hours in the family's sitting room as our source detailed allegations of possible war crimes by KLA officers in a military camp in the Albanian border town of Kukes. It was a crucial interview for a delicate story I have been investigating for years. Mystery of the missing I had met sources who spoke vaguely about secret camps in Albania where Kosovo Serbs, Albanians and Roma were interrogated, tortured and in most cases killed. I met another source who agreed to share important details about KLA prison camps. This man cut a very different profile. He had returned from a successful career abroad to join the KLA in its fight for Kosovo's independence from Serbia. The man was still proud of the goals he fought for, but he had become haunted by the treatment of civilians he had seen at a KLA prison camp. More than that, he said he felt angry and betrayed by KLA commanders who tolerated and even ordered the abuses. "It didn't seem strange at the time," he told me as he described seeing desperate civilians locked in a filthy agricultural shed. He said the civilians were Serbs and Roma seized by KLA soldiers and were being hidden away from Nato troops. The source believes the captives were sent across the border to Albania and killed. "Now, looking back, I know that some of the things that were done to innocent civilians were wrong. A soldier's story Yet another source spoke of driving trucks packed with shackled prisoners - mainly Serbian civilians from Kosovo - to secret locations in Albania where they were eventually killed. He recalled hearing two of the captives begging to be shot rather than tortured and "cut into pieces". "I was sick. I was just waiting for it to end," the source told me. "It was hard. I thought we were fighting a war [of liberation] but this was something completely different." (.....) These are the people Clinton helped in 1999, and Bush recognized their independence in 2008. At the time of their recognition, their “president” was a former KLA member and under suspicion (Wanted, if not a friend of ours) of committing war crimes! This goes along side what Carla Del Ponte wrote in her book last year about organ smuggling in northern Albania. +http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7990984.stm And your point is?... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 I'm not sure about her point - But to my mind the breakup of Yugoslavia was aimed at destroying a powerful country which protected it's resources from exploitation, into a bunch of little countries that could be safely exploited by the West. This was accomplished by pretending that Yugoslav history began with the seizure of the local government of Kossovo by the Yugoslavs - As if the preceding ethnic cleansing of the Serbs (500,000 down to about a hundred thousand) had not occured.) This was accomplished by manipulating the Croats and others into "revolting" against the Central government - And making believe that the US Civil War wasn't a real precedent for us to look at this sudden desire for self determination. Germany for example recognised the "new" Croat government on the same day of their independance. The whole breakup of Yugoslavia was planned from the beginning by Western Corporate interests, and succeded beyond their wildest dreams. And in order for this to occur - There had to be "Bad Guys," and the Serbs fitted the Bill. Dave

We spent hours in the family's sitting room as our source detailed allegations of possible war crimes by KLA officers in a military camp in the Albanian border town of Kukes. It was a crucial interview for a delicate story I have been investigating for years. Mystery of the missing I had met sources who spoke vaguely about secret camps in Albania where Kosovo Serbs, Albanians and Roma were interrogated, tortured and in most cases killed. I met another source who agreed to share important details about KLA prison camps. This man cut a very different profile. He had returned from a successful career abroad to join the KLA in its fight for Kosovo's independence from Serbia. The man was still proud of the goals he fought for, but he had become haunted by the treatment of civilians he had seen at a KLA prison camp. More than that, he said he felt angry and betrayed by KLA commanders who tolerated and even ordered the abuses. "It didn't seem strange at the time," he told me as he described seeing desperate civilians locked in a filthy agricultural shed. He said the civilians were Serbs and Roma seized by KLA soldiers and were being hidden away from Nato troops. The source believes the captives were sent across the border to Albania and killed. "Now, looking back, I know that some of the things that were done to innocent civilians were wrong. But the people who did these things act as if nothing happened, and continue to hurt their own people, Albanians." This man was one of eight former KLA fighters who revealed some of their darkest secrets from the war. A soldier's story Yet another source spoke of driving trucks packed with shackled prisoners - mainly Serbian civilians from Kosovo - to secret locations in Albania where they were eventually killed. He recalled hearing two of the captives begging to be shot rather than tortured and "cut into pieces". "I was sick. I was just waiting for it to end," the source told me. "It was hard. I thought we were fighting a war [of liberation] but this was something completely different." (.....) These are the people Clinton helped in 1999, and Bush recognized their independence in 2008. At the time of their recognition, their “president” was a former KLA member and under suspicion (Wanted, if not a friend of ours) of committing war crimes! This goes along side what Carla Del Ponte wrote in her book last year about organ smuggling in northern Albania. +http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7990984.stm And your point is?... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 C'mon now, you know how it is with Serb Fanbois, they cant take they lost...
quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: quote: Originally posted by NSNN: quote: The man spoke plainly as he explained the horrors he lived through in a Kosovo Liberation Army prison camp 10 years ago. He told me about how he watched people beaten with steel pipes, cut with knives, left for days without food, and shot and killed. "What can you feel when you see those things?" he said. "It's something that is stuck in my mind for the rest of my life. You cannot do those things to people, not even to animals." As the man talked, his mother paced nervously in the nearby kitchen. She was panicked and tears were streaming down her face. "They'll kill him, they'll kill him," she moaned, clutching one of her grandchildren. But her son persisted. We spent hours in the family's sitting room as our source detailed allegations of possible war crimes by KLA officers in a military camp in the Albanian border town of Kukes. It was a crucial interview for a delicate story I have been investigating for years. The man was still proud of the goals he fought for, but he had become haunted by the treatment of civilians he had seen at a KLA prison camp. More than that, he said he felt angry and betrayed by KLA commanders who tolerated and even ordered the abuses. "It didn't seem strange at the time," he told me as he described seeing desperate civilians locked in a filthy agricultural shed. He said the civilians were Serbs and Roma seized by KLA soldiers and were being hidden away from Nato troops. The source believes the captives were sent across the border to Albania and killed. "Now, looking back, I know that some of the things that were done to innocent civilians were wrong. But the people who did these things act as if nothing happened, and continue to hurt their own people, Albanians." This man was one of eight former KLA fighters who revealed some of their darkest secrets from the war.
